title-group.article-title: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Orthodontic Pain Control
title-group.subtitle: A Randomized Trial

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Oral Diseases, West China School of Stomatology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, No. 14, Section 3, Ren Min Nan Road, Chengdu, 610041, P.R. China
2Department of Orthodontics, West China School of Stomatology, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan Province, P.R. China
3Department of Medical Statistics, West China School of Public Health, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan Province, P.R. China
4Department of Epidemiology, West China School of Public Health, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan Province, P.R. China
5Psychiatry Department, West China Hospital, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan Province, P.R. China

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 International & American Associations for Dental Research
permissions.copyright-holder: International & American Associations for Dental Research

abstract.p: The objective of this study was to evaluate the efficacy of cognitive behavioral therapy intervention for patients who experienced pain during orthodontic treatment. The baseline characteristics were assessed via questionnaires and oral examinations. Four hundred and fifty eligible individuals were recruited and randomized by computer-generated block randomization into three groups: cognitive behavioral therapy intervention (n = 150), ibuprofen intervention (n = 150), and no intervention (control; n = 150). Primary outcomes were the change from baseline in pain intensity measured with 100-mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) scores at 1, 2, 3, 7, 14, and 30 days after initial archwire placement. Outcomes assessment was blinded and followed the intention-to-treat principle. One hundred forty-three (95.30%), 145 (96.70%), and 141 (94.00%) individuals in the cognitive behavioral therapy, the ibuprofen, and the control groups, respectively, completed the one-month follow-up evaluations. Those in the cognitive behavioral therapy group showed a greater decrease in mean VAS scores than did those in the control group over the previous five time-points (p < 0.001). Cognitive behavioral therapy was shown to be effective in pain control during the initial stage of orthodontic treatment. The study registration number was ChiCTR-TRC-00000556.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pain during tooth movement is a complex experience accompanying most orthodontic procedures (Bradley et al., 2007). Pain perception appears 2 to 3 hrs after orthodontic appointments, reaches a peak around 24 hrs, and starts to decrease on the third day (Erdinç and Dinçer, 2004). Reported as a major cause of treatment discontinuation, orthodontic pain may even compromise a patient’s daily life (Brown and Moerenhout, 1991).

The most common approach to reducing dental pain in orthodontics is the prescription of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (Bradley et al., 2007; Mehlisch et al., 2010). However, in addition to side-effects, it has been reported that some NSAID drugs could hinder tooth movement, thus prolonging orthodontic treatment (Arias and Marquez-Orozco, 2006). Although some non-pharmacologic and non-invasive measures have been proposed—including biting an anesthetic gel, chewing gum or a plastic wafer, low-level CO2 laser therapy, vibratory stimulation, and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation—their soundness in clinical application, after detailed analysis, remains controversial (Roth and Thrash, 1986; Hwang et al., 1994; Lim et al., 1995; Marie et al., 2003; Mohri et al., 2005). For example, gum chewing and vibratory stimulation must be instituted before the pain sets in, or they will be ineffective or even cause additional pain (Lim et al., 1995; Marie et al., 2003). Thus, analgesics remain the primary therapy for the reduction of orthodontic pain (Bradley et al., 2007). In contrast, all of these measures focus on the physiological factors of pain alone, without referring to the psychological mechanism of pain. Psychological variables play a substantial role in the pain process (Leo, 2008), since it has been proved that pain intensity, threshold, and tolerance are influenced by personality, mood, perception, cognition, etc., and psychological treatments for pain have aroused much attention (Astin, 2004; Kashikar-Zuck, 2006; Leo, 2008; Rivest et al., 2010; Verhoeven et al., 2012). Some researchers have suggested applying psychological behavioral intervention to orthodontic pain (Giddon et al., 2007).

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a typical psychological intervention widely used in pain management (Turner et al., 2005, 2006; Litt et al., 2009, 2010; Lamb et al., 2010). CBT consists mainly of instructions to alter patients’ pain-related thinking, combined with behavioral training (Kashikar-Zuck, 2006; Lamb et al., 2010). In dental care, CBT is primarily used for the management of TMD-related pain (Turner et al., 2005, 2006; Litt et al., 2009, 2010). Superior results were found in the standard treatment plus CBT compared with standard treatment alone for TMD pain reduction (Turner et al., 2006), and the benefits remained over time (Litt et al., 2010). The effectiveness of CBT in burning-mouth syndrome was also proved to be immediate and long-lasting (Bergdahl et al., 1995).
Thus, we hypothesized that CBT may also have an analgesic effect on orthodontic pain. The aim of the study was to assess the efficacy of CBT intervention for managed orthodontic pain.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: The protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of West China Stomatology Hospital (No. 2009025). All of the participants were fully informed and provided signed consent. This study was a registered randomized controlled trial (No. ChiCTR-TRC-00000556).

Inclusion criteria were: (1) patients aged over 10 yrs; (2) patients who were able to comprehend and complete the study; (3) patients who consented to the research procedures and signed an informed consent; and (4) minors with permission from a parent or legal guardian. Individuals were excluded if: (1) they had undergone previous orthodontic treatment; (2) they had recently experienced a toothache; (3) they were diagnosed concurrently as having infectious diseases and/or systemic diseases; (4) they had used analgesics within 3 days prior to orthodontic treatment or exhibited a contraindication to NSAIDs; (5) they displayed excessive anxiety as confirmed by the Trait-Anxiety Inventory (T-AI) score (males, ≥ 56; females, ≥ 57) and State-Anxiety Inventory (S-AI) score (males, ≥ 53; females, ≥ 55) (Shek, 1993); (6) their pain threshold was less than 3 sec or greater than 60 sec; or (7) their endurance time was greater than 5 min according to the cold pressor test (CPT; Johnson and Petrie, 1997). Individuals who failed to comply with the one-month follow-up were excluded and classified as drop-out cases. The intention-to-treat (ITT) was included in the data analysis.

sec.title: Randomization and Masking
sec.p: Eligible patients were randomized into three groups via a computer-generated sequence performed by a Chinese Clinical Trial Registry statistician: CBT intervention, ibuprofen intervention, and no intervention. The randomization sequences were stored in opaque envelopes by two clinicians who were not involved in the enrollment, intervention implementation, or outcome assessments. The outcome assessors and statisticians were blinded to the allocation. Other certified researchers were recruited and trained to provide CBT intervention and deliver ibuprofen. The CBT, ibuprofen, and control treatments were administered by different therapists in three different rooms, to prevent contamination.

Before randomization, each participant received a 15-minute introduction to the study and information regarding orthodontic pain. Baseline questionnaires were administered to all participants, including: the S-AI to evaluate anxiety levels; CPT to measure pain threshold and pain tolerance levels (Johnson and Petrie, 1997); the VAS for pain intensity levels (Huskisson, 1974); the Short Form-36 Health Survey (SF-36; Vignatelli et al., 2004) for life quality measures; and the Eysenck personality questionnaire (EPQ; Smillie et al., 2009) to evaluate personality traits. All participants underwent careful oral examinations before interventions. Before initial archwire placement, the orthodontists recorded treatment-related information regarding the severity of malocclusion, the size of the initial wire, and so on. All participants were given routine instructions regarding dietary habits and oral hygiene maintenance before intervention.

sec.title: Treatment Procedures
sec.p: For the CBT group, a “modified structured cognitive behavioral therapy intervention manual for orthodontic pain management” (Appendix) was established, and all therapists provided CBT interventions according to this manual to ensure a standardized intervention and guarantee the consistency in each therapist’s intervention. CBT intervention was delivered immediately after initial archwire placement. The participants received an initial assessment and one CBT session (lasting 1.5 -2 hrs). The CBT interventions were conducted by 15 therapists who had been trained by a licensed and experienced psychotherapist. Monthly supervision was carried out for the therapists. Regular meetings were held to report and address any problems arising during the intervention process. Compliance with CBT was defined as attendance at the initial assessment and subsequent sessions (including a structured phone call). Randomly selected sessions were audio-recorded and assessed by the licensed and experienced psychologist to ensure that the session content was performed according to the best practices of CBT. The CBT interventions involved guided imagery, activity pacing, relaxation training, assistance in tackling pain-related anxiety, and problem-solving (Kashikar-Zuck, 2006). For cognitive reconstruction, the therapists detailed the pain that might occur and last throughout orthodontic treatment yet be expected to decrease gradually. Daily relaxation training (Appendix Fig.) procedures (15 min) were taught in an audio program with soft background music at patients’ homes when orthodontic pain occurred. Structured phone calls were made by therapists at each observation time-point to remind patients to practice CBT intervention. To ensure consistency, a “Structured phone call procedure” was prepared (Appendix), and all therapists adhered to this procedure when they called patients.
In the ibuprofen group, participants received 300 mg ibuprofen at 6, 12, and 24 hrs after initial archwire placement, with the therapists’ structured calls to remind them at designated time-points.
In the control group, participants received routine diet and hygiene instructions only, with the therapists’ structured calls to remind them at designated time-points.

sec.title: Outcomes Assessment
sec.p: The primary outcome was pain intensity measured by the VAS score (Huskisson, 1974) at each observation point (cross-sectional) and in the entire study duration (longitudinal). The participants were asked to complete a 100-mm VAS, with the left end indicating “no pain” and the right end indicating “extreme pain”. The secondary outcome was life quality assessed by the SF-36 (Vignatelli et al., 2004) and the SAS (Olatunji et al., 2006) at baseline and at 30 days. VAS data were collected on 1, 2, 3, 7, 14, and 30 days after initial archwire placement. The SAS was administered at 7 days, while the SF-36 was administered at 30 days, respectively.

The data were entered into a database by two independent data managers and verified with Epi Data. Multiple imputation analysis for the missing data was used to formulate the ITT dataset (SPSS 18.0, IBM, New York, NY, USA).

Multiple linear regressions were used to test for differences between the VAS scores at 6 time-points, adjusted for possible confounding factors (PCFs). Considering the repeatability of the VAS scores, we initiated a generalized estimating equation (GEE) to test for changing trends in the VAS scores after controlling for PCFs (SAS 9.1, SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We conducted the study between December 2009 and December 2010 at the West China Stomatology Hospital of Sichuan University. The disposition, demographics, and dental characteristics of the participants are shown in Fig. 1 and Appendix Tables 1 and 2. The most frequently reported reasons for discontinuation were unwillingness to complete the follow-up questionnaires (n = 7, 1.6%) and discomfort during orthodontic treatment (n = 7, 1.6%) (Fig. 1). There were no protocol violations in the study. Each of the 15 therapists providing CBT was in charge of 10 participants, 150 in total, and the intra-group differences were not statistically significant.

caption.p: Study flow chart. Enrollment of patients and completion of the study.

sec.p: In the ITT analysis, the three groups differed significantly in sex and mouth breathing (p = 0.012 and 0.002, respectively; Appendix Table 1).

At 30 days, using the Kruskal-Wallis H rank-sum analysis, we noted a significant alleviation (χ2 = 9.780, p = 0.008) in the scale of bodily pain, while there was no significant difference in other variables of the SF-36 results among the three groups. The SAS scores were not significantly different among the groups (F = 1.489, p = 0.227) (Table 1).

caption.p: Baseline Analysis of Quantitative Variables in the Study Participants

fn.p: Kruskal-Wallis H rank-sum test: c2 = 7.279, p = 0.026, indicating a significant difference in age.
Kruskal-Wallis H rank-sum test: c2 = 6.127, p = 0.047, indicating a significant difference in psychoticism.
Kruskal-Wallis H rank-sum test: c2 = 9.780, p = 0.008, indicating a significant difference in bodily pain.

sec.p: The summary multiple regression results for VAS score changes are shown in Table 2. After adjustment for PCFs (age, sex, mouth breathing, and anterior crossbite), the CBT group showed a greater decrease in the mean VAS scores than the control group over the previous 5 time-points, but no significant differences in the score were noted at 30 days. Trends in the patients’ VAS scores were examined by the GEE after adjustment for PCFs (Appendix Table 3). Our results indicated significant differences between the CBT group and the control group (χ2 = 80.190, p < 0.001). Both the CBT and the ibuprofen participants displayed a similar change in pain intensity, and both differed significantly from the control group (Fig. 2).

fn.p: VAS1, VAS2, VAS3, VAS4, VAS5, and VAS6 represent the mean Visual Analogue Scale scores at 1, 2, 3, 7, 14, and 30 days after initial orthodontic archwire placement, respectively. After strict control for inconsistent baseline data, with the exception of the 30-day point, the efficacy in the cognitive behavioral treatment group was better than that observed in the control group at the other 5 time-points.

caption.p: Change in pain scores at 1, 2, 3, 7, 14, and 30 days after initial orthodontic archwire placement. The error bars represent 95% confidence intervals. The participants in the control group received routine instructions regarding dietary habits and oral hygiene maintenance only.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: An important finding of our study was the significant difference in the VAS scores between the CBT and control groups. During the first 3 days after initial archwire placement, the VAS scores in the CBT and ibuprofen groups were distinctly lower than those in the control group, whereas the differences among the groups were statistically significant. Considering that orthodontic pain is most intensely felt 24 hrs after initial archwire placement (Erdinç and Dinçer, 2004) and gradually decreases subsequently, the VAS scores in both the CBT and ibuprofen groups were statistically significantly lower than those in the control group, although the CBT and ibuprofen groups did not differ significantly from each other (Table 2).We also found a significant alleviation in the scale of bodily pain, indicating that CBT was reliable and effective in reducing orthodontic pain.

Orthodontic pain management is indispensable in China for both medical and social reasons. From a medical perspective, individuals affected by this problem are most likely to benefit from a psychological approach. From a social perspective, the number of orthodontic patients is expected to rise in the near future, given China’s rapid economic and social development and its dysfunctional oral health care system.

Though NSAIDs remain the most frequently used method for treating orthodontic pain, certain concerns exist with such medications, especially their side-effects (i.e., neurotoxicity, tolerability, and drug interactions; Bradley et al., 2007). Moreover, in the Chinese culture, people believe that side-effects accompanying medication greatly jeopardize the human body. Chinese individuals may resist taking medications unless it is urgent. Therefore, more often than not, many Chinese parents decline analgesic prescriptions for their children to reduce orthodontic pain, which renders a non-medication-based treatment essential.

CBT has been used in different pain management scenarios, but there are no reports in the literature regarding its effectiveness for orthodontic pain. This was the first study, to date, introducing CBT into orthodontic pain management. We demonstrated the clinical effectiveness of CBT in orthodontic pain management. The short-term effects (≤ 4 mos) were similar to those reported by previous studies focusing on the CBT effect to lower back pain, chronic pain, etc. (Turner et al., 2005, 2006; Litt et al., 2010). Recently, Bartlett and co-workers reported that a telephone call from the dental care provider signiﬁcantly reduced both anxiety and the intensity of self-reported pain (Bartlett et al., 2005). In our study, a structured phone call was made by a therapist on a daily basis to remind participants to practice the CBT interventions at home. The structured telephone calls made in our study are a unique method of guiding CBT self-interventions, which are especially practical in current circumstances in China, where transportation challenges and cost constraints are significant obstacles to traditional clinic-based therapy for many patients with pain (Jerant et al., 2005). It is impractical to gather all patients together in the hospital and conduct all sessions of CBT there, since the patients could afford neither the money nor the time to commute from home to a hospital. Therefore, our CBT program may be suitable for orthodontic pain control in China, both geographically and demographically.

There were certain limitations in this trial. The influence of different races, diagnoses, and treatment preferences on the effectiveness of CBT in orthodontic pain management remains unclear. The patients were recruited and treated in one hospital representing people in southwest China only, and this may affect the validity of our results. Further multicenter randomized controlled trials are needed to exclude those possible influence factors, and thus validate the effectiveness of CBT in orthodontic pain management. Extensive research with CBT applied to chronic orofacial pain does support that brief, multi-session CBT is effective for ameliorating chronic TMD pain (Bergdahl et al., 1995; Good et al., 1999; Turner et al., 2006; Litt et al., 2010). However, there are no clinical trial reports which test the efficacy of a single session of CBT for acute pain elicited by surgical-like dental intervention, as was studied here. As a result, comparisons of the present study with findings from other CBT studies are not yet directly applicable.

Our observations spanned 30 days because a normal visit interval in orthodontic treatment is about 4 to 6 wks, and this observation point was designated to avoid the influence of treatment appliances, force differences, and baseline data assimilation for different orthodontic procedures.

In conclusion, our results suggest that CBT is as effective as ibuprofen in orthodontic pain management, indicating its clinical application potential. Therefore, orthodontists may advise their patients to learn certain pain-coping skills under the conceptual framework of CBT.

ack.p: We thank the dentists in the Department of Orthodontics, West China Stomatology Hospital, for their support and guidance.

A supplemental appendix to this article is published electronically only at http://jdr.sagepub.com/supplemental.
